'The Clouds of Sils Maria' requires two viewings but it contains three great performances by Juliette Binoche, Kristen Stewart and Chloe Grace Moretz. This movie is a compelling, well written essay on stardom and aging actresses. Close attention needs to be paid to this deep, 'All About Eve' type drama updated smartly for an audience starving for great acting in an adult film.

Clouds of Sils Maria is one that benefits from having no expectations beforehand. Given that I hadn't so much as seen a trailer, I didn't really know what I was getting myself into other than its basic setup. Less than that, actually--I really knew keywords from the plot's synopsis and who the movie stars. It also probably helps that I don't mind slow movies since this is one of the slowest of the year. It's also one of the best of the year so far, being a beautifully shot and meditative exploration of how art parallels life and how life parallels art. It's a little surprising to see a movie as meta as Clouds of Sils Maria that doesn't bother going w humorous route. There are some giggles in the characters' realistic interactions, sure, but the movie is definitely a drama. It finds different ways to explore the falling celebrity of Juliette Binoche's character by treating its plot like the other half to its themes instead of a counterpart to its themes. There are moments in which Binoche's character is shown running lines for the main upcoming play that make it confusing whether her character is truly distraught or just giving a convincing performance within the film's universe. Kristen Stewart further disproves the myth that she's nothing more than Bella Swan, and Chloe Grace Moretz gives humanity to child star that easily could have become a caricature. The filmmaking compliments this as well, given how each scene ends with a fade to black as if its characters are existing within a stage production that drops the curtain at the end of their conversations. The story divides itself by title cards--part one, part two, and epilogue--that deny the audience the closure that the characters themselves are striving for. It could easily come off as incomplete or lazy, but it works wonderfully. The movie isn't without its flaws, though, as its pacing has some issues. It starts off well enough but feels a little lost from the 15-minute mark to the 35-minute mark in where it's trying to go or how long it should take. The last fifteen minutes are also a bit spotty and despite its strong end note, the film feels like it has false endings. Otherwise, Clouds of Sils Maria is a hidden gem with a sense of beautiful confusion that is likely to stick with me for a while. 8.4/10, great, one thumb up, definitely above average, etc.

really well done. The trio of ladies at the helm of this all give fantastic performances. Juliette Binoche takes this movie by the reins and doesn't let go. Maria (her character) is facing an uncertain point in her career. She's getting older, movies are changing, the man who helped launch her career passes away, and now she takes on the older character in the play that made her famous. She's faced with a lot, and Maria hides behind the text of the play instead of really confronting her fears. She blames the play and says she can't connect to the character when really she doesn't want to. And Binoche lets us see all of that. Kristen Stewart as her personal assistant makes an excellent scene partner for Binoche. The scenes where the two of them are running lines form the play are fascinating to watch. The line between them running lines and talking normally blurs constantly. Stewart's Val constantly tries to push Maria into seeing new ways of looking at not only the acting world, but the world in general. Throw in Chloe Grace Moretz as the young superstar that's going to be playing Maria's old part, and we have ourselves a movie. It meanders a long a little bit, but the conversations are almost too fascinating to care. I really enjoyed this, and I think not only is it a great movie for theatre people to watch, but also in general as a really interesting character study.

Olivier Assayas' mysterious film is one of the most duplicitous films about stardom, as it is a film that show's its true colors in the most subdued fashion imaginable. Casting veteran actress Juliette Binoche with the younger generation of Kristen Stewart and Chloe Grace Moretz, the film is a very transcendent look at generational gaps, and how aging can be the most unwanted inevitability in the acting world. The trio of actresses all deliver remarkable work here, and in many ways mark the culmination of Olivier Assayas' career as a (potentially) feminist director. Bolstered by lush cinematography, and a script that's both surreal and palpable, Clouds of Sils Maria is quite unlike anything else you'll see in theaters this year.

Despite terrific performances by Juliette Binoche and Kristen Stewart, as well as some gorgeous cinematography, this talky, pretentious, overrated exercise in self-importance never gets off the ground nor sustains its momentum. Tossing together a collection of pithy insights into a single vehicle and hoping the finished product makes sense is no way to craft a film. Save your time and money.

As with all French films, I offer a degree of leniency when it comes to the overall pulse of the film. French movies are notoriously boring and despite the fact that films should not be so, I am happy to offer passes to films like Rust and Bone and Two Days, One Night. Clouds of Sils Maria however, takes advantage of my good graces, offering a boxed in two hours of what is honestly some of the most lifeless film I have had the displeasure of watching. A great deal of this centers around the Stewart casting. Although many a director has attempted to take the credit for rescuing young adult actor's careers, there is rarely credit to take. As was the case with Daniel Radcliffe, Stewart is an inherently bad actress. She has no range, no emotion and poor vocalization. Despite the fact that Clouds does its best to fit Stewart into a role that matches her drab exterior, her inability to emotionally connect with a scene still shines through bright and clear. Binoche is strong individually, although her abilities are somewhat lost in the doldrum created by the film. The attitude overall is painfully pretentious, with unwarranted cuts to black and pristine Alps shots to remind us to tune in on Oscar night. Chloe Grace Moretz, hyped by the trailer as a major player in the film, turns out to only have a few minutes of screen time that offers one semi-decent line. Her role is minimal and the dynamic that is attempted between Stewart and Binoche goes on for far too long without really assuming the emotional gravity intended for it. As a final damnation, the film, coming in on the coat tails of the fantastic Birdman, really feels like a free loader, offering a similar look at an aging thespian with many of the same conflicts. The hinted (and undelivered) lesbian spin is really just decor on what really is a shameless awards bait copycat. Clouds of Sils Maria is altogether overhyped, overrated and underwhelming in all aspects.

Assayas' essay on actors' approach to their craft and our society is good, but too elusive to prevent greatness. Kristen Stewart proved (to those who still needed) that she's an accomplished actress who has a lot to give to the industry. All in all, Sils Maria is interesting enough to follow along, yet lacking the depth of superior filmmaking.

Interesting arthouse movie with quite a simple premise but the best thing about it is watching Juliette Binoche (who is always perfect in her roles) and Kristen Stewart, who is a lot more than Bella Swan from the Twilight movies.

A movie trapped in the past about not being trapped in the past, CLOUDS OF SILS MARIA is one more mixed bag of pretension from Olivier Assayas. The ideas are there, the depth, the themes but the execution once again fails. Kristen Stewart, however, is a revelation! She gets it, breaking through the pretense to explore the depths only imagined by the rest of this film. Her shifts from "reality" to "acting" are quite frankly, awesome and amazing. And exactly what CLOUDS OF SILS MARIA is all about.

Probably to crittique it simply Clouds of Sils Maria is best considered as the feminine version of Birdman with a middle aged actress played by Juliet Binoche, going to a tribute to the filmmaker who made her a star, being seduced/obliged to pay tribute to him after his sudden death b suicide to return to the project they did together but now in the adult role and have a young upstart, played here by Chloe Moretz, to play the young she originated which tosses her into a career and identity crisis of sorts. The acting is extremely solid, even by Stewart proving that given the material she can hold her own outside of Twilight and against Oscar winners such as Juliet, and Juliet was deserving of some more awards attention just for her emotional range here. This is an english version of a "french film" so it is already supposed to be artsy. The scenery was beautiful which they take advantage of by spending a lot of time walking all over its trails and sitting to look at the views which is part of the story. Clouds of Sils Maria is a Swiss town where the clouds at some times of the year follow and snakes through the canyons of the alps as it moves and undulates into the mountain/lake town. The topic is also promising, it is about an aging actress struggling to still be relevant as she is being replaced by younger more outrageous, scandal/paparazzi hyped stars. The scenes spends so much time developing the characters and the conflicts that you are promised so much as you follow it...suffering through its editing techniques (it shows the characters without conversations going in and out of houses, cars, etc...just to elaborate the narrative) and filming gimmicks (filmed in 35 mm, which made the beautiful scenery flat). The actors were sufficiently effective...but it all felt so "written" and contrived. One of the main characters just vanishes from the story without explanation or reaction after so much time spent developing the character and the relationship. It's all set up and the end so small, it just felt uneven. It had an interesting topic but makes no lasting impression on them. So much atmosphere but ultimately as insubstantial as a cloud. It was written and directed by Olivier Assayas and it won the Louis Delluc Prize for Best Film in December 2014 but here's where the rubber meets the road: it was made for $6.6M and made $1.5M. Ahhh we uncouth viewers don't know a thing about art french films!

What a terrific film! Juliette Binoche and Kristen Stewart both give stellar performances. The use of music is very much on point throughout the film and the editing, that seemed a bit off at first, makes more and more sense as the movie progresses. For me, this was easily a 5 star movie (the 5 star-est I've seen in a long while) but I'll settle with 4,5 because the epilogue, for me, took away a little bit of the power contained in how part two ended. I don't think the epilogue is unimportant and dispensable, but I am a sucker for open ended films and I find that without the epilogue the ending was more open. It's a personal thing, not a demerit in any way.

Art mirrors art in the transfixing "Clouds of Sils Maria." Veteran actress Maria Enders (Juliette Binoche) is asked to star in the revival of an acclaimed lesbian drama that made her famous 20 years ago, but this time, she must play the older woman, instead of the ingï¿½nue. Confiding in her personal assistant, Val (Kristen Stewart), Maria reflects on her past career and life, and the uncertainty of her future as an aging actress. Binoche captivates with her nuanced performance, balancing Maria's confidence and poise with her wistfulness and insecurity. Holding her own against Binoche, Stewart proves her formidability as an actress; she is sharp and understated, articulating every line of dialogue with unassuming veracity. The most compelling arc in Olivier Assayas's character study is the complex, interdependent relationship between Maria and Val, two strong-minded, intellectual women who care deeply for one another, but never confront their emotions directly. Playing these characters with vulnerability and restraint, Binoche and Stewart have a chemistry that's strikingly palpable. They have such an honest connection to the material that scenes of them conversing and rehearsing seem to bleed into one another, making it difficult to tell whether they are speaking in the present moment or reading lines. Despite its expository dialogue, the narrative is still rich with subtext. Assayas's meta-drama is thoughtful, layered and subtly provocative.
